items.title: Schools Superintendent in Iowa, Arrested by ICE, Plans to Resign
items.summary: A lawyer for Ian Roberts, superintendent of Des Moines Public Schools, announced that Dr. Roberts would step down.

items.title: Harvard Blasts Administration Over ‘Inaccurate’ Civil Rights Investigation
items.summary: The Sept. 19 letter came days before the Department of Health and Human Services started the process of cutting off federal funds to the university.

items.title: Bobby Cain, Barrier Breaker in School Desegregation, Dies at 85
items.summary: In 1957, facing down white mobs, he became the first Black student to graduate from a public high school in the South under a court mandate.

items.title: Gov. Jeff Landry Wants National Guard Troops Deployed in Louisiana
items.summary: Gov. Jeff Landry’s request to the Trump administration highlights how Republican-led states are embracing the president’s push to use the Guard to crack down on crime.

items.title: Deadlock Grows Uglier as Congress Heads Toward Government Shutdown
items.summary: President Trump’s posting of a deepfake video mocking and insulting the top two Democrats in Congress underscored the lack of progress toward any deal to extend funding.

items.title: Hegseth Lectures Military Brass on ‘Woke’ Leaders, Fitness and Grooming
items.summary: Senior officers, summoned from around the world, are entrusted to manage complex military operations. They got a lecture on fitness and grooming standards.

items.title: Trump says government shutdown likely as House Democrats call out Republicans for delaying votes before funding deadline – live
items.summary: <p>Government funding is set to expire at midnight ET; Republican speaker Mike Johnson pushed back House return in order to prevent Democrats from negotiating further</p><p><strong>The US government is hurtling towards its first shutdown in six years, with no signs <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-congress">congressional</a> leaders are near agreement on legislation to continue funding beyond the Tuesday night deadline to prevent workers from being furloughed and agencies from shutting their doors.</strong></p><p>Congress’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/republicans">Republican</a> majority is pushing legislation to fund the government through 21 November, but Democrats have refused to vote for it unless it includes a series of concessions centered on healthcare.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2025/sep/30/us-government-shutdown-funding-trump-vance-portland-hegseth-latest-updates">Continue reading...</a>

items.title: What is a government shutdown and why is this year’s threat more serious?
items.summary: <p>US government will shut down on 1 October if Congress cannot reach a funding agreement. Here is what to know</p><p>The federal government is once again on the brink of a shutdown, unless <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-congress">Congress</a> can reach a funding agreement before the start of the new fiscal year, on 1 October.</p><p>With the clock ticking and both Democrats and Republicans seemingly dug in, there is little time left to avoid a lapse in government funding. And in a sharp escalation, the White House has threatened permanent mass layoffs of government workers in the event of a shutdown, adding to the roughly <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/sep/28/us-mass-resignation-federal-workers">300,000 </a>it forced out earlier this year.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/sep/27/government-shutdown-explainer">Continue reading...</a>
